The company should count how many screens are bad based of the data from the engineer. They should then calculate how many screens make up 5% of 150 by multiplying 150 by .05. If the number of broken screens is greater than the value calculated, they should reject the order.

If 8 or more of the screens are faulty, the electronics company should reject the order of display screens because if more than 5% of the screens (7.5 mathematically rounded up to 8) are faulty then there's no opportunity cost in returning them for a refund and getting a new batch that may have less faulty screens.

The mean fish lengths and variance of fish lengths for each fisherman's catch can be calculated.  A two sample t-test can then be used to determine whether there exists a significant difference in mean lengths between the two samples.  If there exists a significant difference in mean lengths, the better fisherman can be determined.
The engineer will determine that 5% of 150 monitors is about 7.5 monitors.  Thus, if 8 monitors are defective, the engineer will reject the order.

state null and alternative hypothesis: / h0: there is no difference between mean lenghts of the fish that the two brothers catched. Ha: there is a difference between the mean lenghts of the fish that the two brothers catched.  /  / compute the means of the lenghts of all fish that the two brothers caught.  /  / find the p value,, first determine the standard error of the difference between the two sample means. (square root of squared SE mark + squared SE Dan).  /  / calulcate the observed difference (yhat mark - yhat dan)  /  / find the t value using technology.  /  / is the P value is bigger than 0.05, then the null hypothesis is rejected, hence there is a difference between the fish caught by dan and mark. to find out who caught the bigger ones, a side by side boxplot can be made.

Statistical inference can be used in this scenario.  The method could use two categories (correct or incorrect) and compare whether there exists a tendency for Carla to choose the correct note.  Without an existing statistic to compare Carla's proportion to, however, there is no way to know if Carla has a "good" ear for music.

First calculate the mean and standard deviation for Mark and Dan. / Than determine the confidence interval (95%) for Mark. / If Dan's mean is in the confidence interval than they are equal. / If Dan's mean is greater than the confidence interval than Dan is better. / If Dan's mean is less than the confidence interval than Mark is better.
Yes this instance could use statistical inference. You could easily figure out who catches on average the largest fishes by simple statistics.

1. Get a sample: i.e. let the teacher play a note 50 times, and let the student guess 50 times  / 2. Let's say that if the has good hearing, the chance of success, getting the right note, is 0.9. This leads us to the hypothesis: h0: p=0.9. ha: p<0.9  / 3. Calculate phat: number of successes/n  / 4. Calculate the z score  / 5. calculate the p-value  / 6. State your conclusion: is the p is small, then the chance of getting the observed number of successes is very small assuming that the null hypothesis is true. this means that we rejected the hypothesis that she has a good hearing.
